definitions.definition: The language of a people or a national language.
examples: The vernacular of the United States is English.

definitions.definition: Everyday speech or dialect , including colloquialisms , as opposed to standard , literary , liturgical , or scientific idiom .
examples: Street vernacular can be quite different from what is heard elsewhere.

definitions.definition: Language unique to a particular group of people.
examples: For those of a certain age, hiphop vernacular might just as well be a foreign language.

definitions.definition: A language lacking standardization or a written form.
Indigenous spoken language, as distinct from a literary or liturgical language such as Ecclesiastical Latin .
examples: Vatican II, a church council in the 1960s, allowed the celebration of the mass in the vernacular .

definitions.definition: A style of architecture involving local building materials and styles ; not imported .

main_definition: The language of a people or a national language.
secondary_definitions: Everyday speech or dialect , including colloquialisms , as opposed to standard , literary , liturgical , or scientific idiom .
Language unique to a particular group of people.
A language lacking standardization or a written form.
Indigenous spoken language, as distinct from a literary or liturgical language such as Ecclesiastical Latin .
( architecture ) A style of architecture involving local building materials and styles ; not imported .
